claim: The Gunpowder plot did eliminate Mary, Queen of Scots bloodline.

supporting.text: Mary, Queen of Scots was executed in 1587, nearly two decades before the Gunpowder Plot in 1605.

attacks.text: Mary, Queen of Scots was executed in 1587, nearly two decades before the Gunpowder Plot in 1605.
The Gunpowder Plot was aimed at King James I, who was Mary's son, thus potentially affecting her bloodline indirectly.
The Gunpowder Plot failed, so it had no actual impact on James I or Mary's bloodline.
Mary's bloodline continued through James I and his descendants, regardless of the Gunpowder Plot's intentions.

supporting.text: The Gunpowder Plot targeted King James I and Parliament, not the descendants of Mary, Queen of Scots.

attacks.text: The Gunpowder Plot targeted King James I and Parliament, not the descendants of Mary, Queen of Scots.
While the Gunpowder Plot did not directly target Mary's descendants, its failure led to stricter anti-Catholic laws that indirectly weakened her bloodline's influence.
The anti-Catholic laws post-Gunpowder Plot primarily targeted active conspirators, not the broader Stuart bloodline, which retained political power.
Mary, Queen of Scots was executed in 1587, long before the Gunpowder Plot, so her bloodline's fate was already sealed independently.

supporting.text: Mary's son, James VI of Scotland, became James I of England, continuing her bloodline through his descendants.

attacks.text: Mary's son, James VI of Scotland, became James I of England, continuing her bloodline through his descendants.
The Gunpowder Plot was aimed at killing James I and his heirs, which would have ended Mary's bloodline in England.
Even if the Gunpowder Plot had succeeded, Mary's bloodline could have continued through other descendants in Scotland or Europe.
Historical records show no significant surviving branches of Mary's bloodline outside of James I's descendants by the time of the Gunpowder plot.

supporting.text: Historical records confirm that the Stuart dynasty, descended from Mary, ruled England and Scotland after the Gunpowder Plot.

attacks.text: Historical records confirm that the Stuart dynasty, descended from Mary, ruled England and Scotland after the Gunpowder Plot.
The Gunpowder Plot was aimed at King James I, not the entire Stuart dynasty, so its failure did not eliminate Mary's bloodline.
The plot's failure ensured the survival of James I and his descendants, who continued the Stuart line.
Even if the plot had succeeded, other Stuart descendants existed who could have continued Mary's bloodline.

supporting.text: The Gunpowder Plot's failure ensured the survival of James I and his heirs, who were direct descendants of Mary, Queen of Scots.

attacks.text: The Gunpowder Plot's failure ensured the survival of James I and his heirs, who were direct descendants of Mary, Queen of Scots.
Mary, Queen of Scots was executed in 1587, long before the Gunpowder Plot in 1605, so the plot's failure is irrelevant to her bloodline's survival.
While Mary was executed earlier, the Gunpowder Plot's failure ensured the continuity of James I's reign, which indirectly preserved her bloodline through his descendants.
Mary's bloodline could have survived through other descendants not related to James I, making the Gunpowder Plot's impact on her lineage less direct.
